dt: {bc}of or relating to a group of animals typified by (such) a form
{bc}of or relating to a plant family

et: borrowed from Latin {it}-āceus{/it} "having the nature of," extended form of {it}-eus,{/it} going back to {it}*ei̯os{/it}

Latin {it}-āceus{/it} is an extension of the suffix {it}-eus,{/it} meaning "being made of, consisting of," usually applied to a noun designating a material ({it}aureus, argenteus,{/it} etc.). Earlier attested derivatives, from Cato and Varro, are from names of plants or plant-based substances ({it}hederāceus,{/it} cf. {it}hedera{/it} "ivy"; {it}mustāceus/mustāceum{/it} "cake made with must ({it}mustum{/it}) and ivy leaves"; {it}vīnāceus{/it} "refuse from wine pressing"; {it}bētāceus,{/it} cf. {it}bēta{/it} "beet"; {it}farrāceus,{/it} cf. {it}farr, farris{/it} "emmer"; {it}lolleāceus,{/it} cf. {it}lolium{/it} "darnel"). Contrasting with these are the jocular formations {it}gallīnāceus{/it} ("of poultry"; cf. {it}gallīna{/it} "hen") and {it}Gēryonāceus{/it} (cf. {it}Gēryōn,{/it} a mythical monster) in Plautus. The origin of the {it}-āc-{/it} formative is uncertain. It has been suggested that the basis was re-segmentation of a hypothetical {it}*portulāceus,{/it} from {it}portulāca,{/it} "purslane"—something of a stretch, though it does point to the possible relevance of {it}-ācus{/it} or {it}-āca{/it} as a suffix itself.
shortdef: consisting of : having the nature or form of
of or relating to a group of animals typified by (such) a form or characterized by (such) a feature
